dc:description: LITAF/SIMPLE was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease in 2003 (Street et al., 2003; PMID: 12525712). The phenotypes associated with LITAF/SIMPLE variants include distal muscle weakness, pes cavus, decreased motor and sensory nerve conduction velocities, and impaired vibration or pain sensation in the lower limbs. At least 15 unique missense variants have been reported in humans, with few other types of mutations reported. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, segregation and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in over 25 probands in 6 different publications, although no confirmed de novo or null variants have been observed in the literature (PMIDs: 24880540, 19541485, 28211240, 16787513, 15776429, 12525712). Variants in this gene also segregated with disease in over 50 additional family members across seven different families. This gene-disease relationship is supported by expression studies, functional studies, and an animal model. LITAF/SIMPLE was once predicted to have a role in protein degradation pathways, however recent research has shown that it is instead a zinc-binding membrane protein that embeds itself with an anchor located within the LITAF domain where most of the pathogenic mutations cluster (PMID: 27927196). Additionally, LITAF/SIMPLE is present in both developing and adult rat/mouse schwann cells and not in the axons supporting a demyelinating neuropathy phenotype (PMID:12525712). In summary, LITAF/SIMPLE is MODERATELY associated with autosomal dominant Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing contradictory evidence has emerged. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Charcot Marie Tooth Gene Curation Expert Panel on Apr 7, 2020.

evidence.dc:description: Although the mice with the expressed transgene do display signs clearly indicative of CMT1, the lack of specificity in the transfection and the promoter used do not allow for a preponderance of evidence to be met particularly as the heterozygous mice showed significantly less of a phenotype than the homozygous for an Autosomal Dominant disorder. Therefore, this model is downgraded to 1.0 points.

Subcellular fractionation analysis confirmed that some amount of the W116G protein mislocalized to the mitochondira/cytosol in the sciatic nerves while the WT protien localizes to the membrane as per normal. Phenotypically, both homozygous W116G and heterozygous mice showed general signs of muscle weakness and abnormal clenching signs upon tail hanging, suggestive of abnormal motor function. Impaired motor performance in the rotarod test was also noted in both compared to the controls, and a decrease in the tail-flick test showed reduced sensory perception. Further investigation revealed decreases in both motor and sensory nerve conduction velocities in both lines of mice, as well as decreased CMAPs, with SIMPLE WT transgenic mice displaying none of the aforementioned symptoms showing clear deficits that are consistent with human CMT. Histological analysis of sciatic nerves and ventral/dorsal roots revealed a demyelinating phenotype in the homozygous W116G mice with abnormal myelin infolding more prominent in the sciatic nerves. The axon caliber/area was much smaller than that of non-transgenic controls but no axon loss was noted. Analysis displayed that these axons with infoldings were displaced or deformed causing axonal damage and degeneration. The aforementioned loops were determined to likely physically block proper axonal transport leading to the degeneration and phenotypes observed in the mice and humans. This is further supported by microscopic analysis of different ages of mice that show the myelin infoldings precede the axonal defects in the mouse cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Transgenic W116G Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: This experiment shows a clearly altered protein when the hydrophobic helical region or the known pathogenic mutant V144M is expressed in the cells. This altered stability and mislocalization can lead to dysfunctional membrane trafficking and eventually to the phenotypes observed in CMT1. Therefore, this evidence earns default points.

The altered LITAF constructs showed mislocalization in the soluble fraction as opposed to the membrane pellets after fractionation. The LITAF altered constructs also displayed a decreased ability to coordinate zinc atoms and therefore was more succeptible to improper folding. Removing this domain also caused the wild-type's interaction with PE-head groups to decrease in the mutant leading to protein instability. The V144M mutant construct also decreases the protein's stability significantly, pointing towards misfolding and deleterious effects on intracellular membranes.
evidence.rdfs:label: LITAF Δ114–139 shows Mislocalization and Decreased Stability

evidence.dc:description: Since the predicted function of LITAF as a membrane trafficking protein with disrupted function could feasibly cause the phenotypes we see in CMT1, this evidence earns default points.

According to PMID:31173589, many schwann cell proteins responsible for maintaining the stability and function of compact myelin have variants that can cause Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease or other related neuropathies. Without the ability to functionally transmit materials or form the proper structures in the schwann cells, myelin sheaths can begin degrading and cause the phenotypes that we observe in CMT Type 1.
evidence.rdfs:label: LITAF as an Integral Membrane Component

evidence.dc:description: Although LITAF is near-ubiquitously expressed, investigation showed here that it is highly expressed in both developing and adult nerves and is upregulated after crush injury suggesting a role in disease pathogenesis. The myelin vs axonal expression is also relevant due to LITAF resulting in a demyelinating neuropathy. Therefore, this evidence earns default points.

Northern blot analysis in rat sciatic nerve biopsy yielded moderate expression in both adult and developing nerve tissue. Additionally, when crush injury was performed, a general increase in Litaf expression over a 58-day time course was observed more pronounced proximal vs distal to the injury site. When investigated in PMID:22729949, the LITAF expression was clearly exclusive to the myelin sheath rather than the axons supporting the pathogenesis of a demyelinating neuropathy.
evidence.rdfs:label: LITAF/SIMPLE Expression

evidence.dc:description: Phenotypic evidence combined with variant-level evidence (PMID: 12525712 shows mislocalization and structural alterations) gives this proband default points.

evidence.rdfs:label: GCP5

evidence.rdfs:label: K1550:II-7
evidence.detectionMethod: Haplotype analysis and linkage analysis was was performed with microsattelite markersand PCR amplification being performed. A combined LOD score of 14.25 was obtained with marker D16S500, establishing a link with chromosome 16p13.1-p12.3. This was further narrowed to a 9-cM interval between markers D16S519 and D16S764. In this paper, genomic DNA was obtained and exons 2-4 of LITAF were PCR amplified and sequenced with variants found in Exon 3. Restriction digest confirmed the mutation cosegregated with the disease in both families.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Mean ulnar (16.7 m/s [n = 3], 25.3 [n = 8]), median (23 m/s [n = 5], 25.8 m/s [n = 12], and peroneal (20.4 m/s [n = 4], 21 m/s [n = 6]) motor nerve conduction velocities (MNCV)
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Motor-nerve conduction velocities of less than 38 m/s; Negative LOD score for PMP22, MPZ, and EGR2; Male-to-male transmission is present ruling out X-linked inheritance, Sural nerve biopsy taken during reconstructive foot surgery

evidence.dc:description: This proband has phenotypic evidence, however the suspected pathogenic variant has a gnomAD frequency and no functional studies. Therefore, this scores 0.1 points.

evidence.rdfs:label: II-1
evidence.detectionMethod: The duplication/deletion of 17p11.2 region and point mutations in CMT1-related genes (MPZ, PMP22, EGR2 and LITAF/SIMPLE) were investigated in the proband and in the other available affected subjects. The only positive result came from LITAF/SIMPLE with bidirectional direct sequencing showing a mutation. The variant segregated with disease in both affected and unaffected family members.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Slight reduction in the number of the myelinated and unmyelinated fibers; Myelin fibers had a very thin myelin sheath compared to axonal diameter; Extensor longus hallucis and extensor digitorum brevis weakness
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The presence of a Martin-Gruber anastomosis was excluded

evidence.dc:description: Phenotypic evidence combined with variant-level evidence (PMID: 27927196 shows structural alteration and altered interaction with PE head groups and deleterious effects on membranes) gives this proband default points.

evidence.rdfs:label: GE
evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was extracted from blood samples. Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification was used to test for PMP22 duplication or GJB1, MPZ, and EGR2. With those ruled out the LITAF exons were PCR ampified and directly sequenced locating a missense mutation in both the proband and her son.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Relevant nerve conduction velocities and other numbers in Table 1, Diagnosed with a mild demyelinating sensorimotor polyneuropathy
